Habitat.Distribution: Tropical and temperate forests

PhysicalTraits.Color: Orange with black stripes and white undersides

Behavior.Communication: Roars, growls, chuffs, scent marking

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: High
HumanInteraction.Notes: Apex predator, culturally significant

FunFacts: Each tiger's stripe pattern is unique, like human fingerprints.
Tigers are strong swimmers and often hunt in water.

Habitat.Distribution: Tropical and subtropical forests, grasslands, swamps

PhysicalTraits.Color: Tan or orange with black rosettes
SpecialTraits: Strongest bite of any big cat proportional to size

Behavior.Communication: Roars, grunts, huffs, scent marking

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: Medium
HumanInteraction.Notes: Largest cat in the Americas

FunFacts: Jaguars are known for their powerful jaws, capable of piercing turtle shells.
They are often found near water sources.

Classification.Species: Various (e.g., Bradypus variegatus for Brown-throated Sloth)

Habitat.Distribution: Tropical and subtropical forests

PhysicalTraits.Color: Brownish-gray with greenish algae on fur (camouflage)

Behavior.ActivityTime: Mostly nocturnal but can be active during the day
Behavior.Communication: Hissing, squeaking, grunting (infrequent)

ConservationStatus.IUCNStatus: Various (e.g., Least Concern to Critically Endangered depending on species)
ConservationStatus.PopulationTrend: Estimated: Varies by species, some decreasing due to habitat loss

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: Low
HumanInteraction.Notes: Known for their extremely slow movement

FunFacts: Sloths descend from trees once a week to defecate.
Their slow metabolism means they can take up to a month to digest a meal.

Habitat.Distribution: Temperate forests of the Himalayas

PhysicalTraits.Color: Reddish-brown with white markings on face and darker fur on belly
SpecialTraits: False thumb (modified wrist bone) for gripping bamboo
Long bushy tail for balance and warmth

Behavior.Communication: Twittering, squeaking, huffing, tail flicking

Threats: Poaching for fur and pet trade

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: Low
HumanInteraction.Notes: Often confused with the giant panda

FunFacts: Red pandas are excellent climbers and spend most of their time in trees.
They use their long, bushy tails as blankets in cold weather.

Habitat.Distribution: Dense rainforests of Central Africa

PhysicalTraits.Size: Estimated: 1.9-2.5 meters long, 1.5-2.0 meters tall at shoulder
PhysicalTraits.Color: Dark chocolate brown body with distinctive white and black striped legs
SpecialTraits: Long, prehensile tongue (up to 30 cm) for stripping leaves

Behavior.Communication: Chuffs, coughs, bleats, infrasound (estimated)

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: Low
HumanInteraction.Notes: Often called a 'living fossil' due to its ancient lineage

FunFacts: The okapi's stripes help them blend into the dappled light of the forest.
They can clean their own eyelids and ears with their long tongue.

Habitat.Distribution: Tropical forests and savannas of Central and West Africa

PhysicalTraits.Color: Black fur with bare faces (can vary with age and subspecies)
SpecialTraits: Highly intelligent with complex social structures

Behavior.Communication: Vocalizations (hoots, screams, grunts), facial expressions, body language, gestures

Threats: Poaching for bushmeat and pet trade

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: Medium (can be aggressive if threatened)
HumanInteraction.Notes: Closest living relatives to humans

FunFacts: Chimpanzees use a variety of tools, including sticks to extract insects and leaves to absorb water.
They have unique personalities and form strong bonds within their communities.

animalInfo.ScientificName: Pongo (e.g., Pongo pygmaeus for Bornean Orangutan)

Classification.Species: Various (e.g., Pongo pygmaeus, Pongo abelii, Pongo tapanuliensis)

Habitat.Distribution: Tropical rainforests of Borneo and Sumatra

PhysicalTraits.Color: Reddish-brown long shaggy fur
SpecialTraits: Long, powerful arms for brachiation (swinging through trees)

Behavior.SocialType: Semi-solitary (mothers with offspring, males mostly alone)
Behavior.Communication: Long calls (males), grunts, squeaks, facial expressions, gestures

Reproduction.ReproductionCycle: Estimated: Every 6-8 years (longest interbirth interval among great apes)

Threats: Habitat loss due to palm oil plantations and logging

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: Low (generally shy, but can defend if threatened)
HumanInteraction.Notes: Arboreal apes, rarely descend to the ground

FunFacts: Orangutans build elaborate nests in trees for sleeping.
Their name means 'person of the forest' in Malay.

Habitat.Distribution: Forests near water bodies (rivers, lakes, swamps) in South America

PhysicalTraits.Color: Reddish-brown to grayish fur
SpecialTraits: Eyes, ears, and nostrils on top of head for staying submerged

Behavior.Communication: Grunts, chirps, whistles, barks (alarm calls)

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: Low (generally docile, but can bite if threatened)
HumanInteraction.Notes: Largest rodent in the world

FunFacts: Capybaras can stay submerged underwater for up to 5 minutes.
They are often seen resting in water to regulate their body temperature.

Classification.Species: Various (e.g., Ramphastos toco for Toco Toucan)

Habitat.Distribution: Tropical and subtropical forests of Central and South America

PhysicalTraits.Color: Black plumage with brightly colored bills and facial markings
SpecialTraits: Zygodactyl feet (two toes forward, two backward) for gripping branches

Behavior.Communication: Loud, distinct calls (frog-like croaks, yelps), bill clacking

ConservationStatus.IUCNStatus: Various (e.g., Least Concern to Vulnerable depending on species)
ConservationStatus.PopulationTrend: Estimated: Varies by species, some decreasing due to habitat loss

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: Low
HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Protected in many areas, sometimes kept as pets (often illegally)
HumanInteraction.Notes: Iconic bird of the rainforest

FunFacts: Despite its large size, a toucan's bill is very light because it's mostly hollow bone.
They use their bill to regulate body temperature.

animalInfo.ScientificName: Gorilla gorilla (Western Gorilla) or Gorilla beringei (Eastern Gorilla)

Habitat.Distribution: Tropical and subtropical forests of Central and East Africa

PhysicalTraits.Color: Black fur (Western Gorilla), darker or browner (Eastern Gorilla)
SpecialTraits: Highly intelligent with complex social structures

Behavior.SocialType: Social (family groups led by a silverback male)
Behavior.Communication: Vocalizations (grunts, hoots, screams, roars), chest-beating, facial expressions, body posture

Threats: Poaching for bushmeat and trophy hunting

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: Medium (generally shy, but can be dangerous if provoked or feel threatened)
HumanInteraction.Notes: Gentle giants, crucial for forest health

FunFacts: Gorillas share about 98% of their DNA with humans.
Silverback gorillas are the dominant male leaders of a group.

Habitat.Distribution: Tropical rainforests of Southeast Asia

PhysicalTraits.Color: Shaggy black fur, often with gray-tipped hairs
PhysicalTraits.Lifespan: Estimated: 18-25 years (in captivity, less in wild)
SpecialTraits: Prehensile tail used like a fifth limb
Smells like popcorn or buttered toast

Behavior.Communication: Chirps, purrs, growls, hisses, scent marking (popcorn smell)

Reproduction.ReproductionCycle: Estimated: Can breed year-round, 1-2 litters per year

Threats: Poaching for meat, traditional medicine, and pet trade

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: Low (generally shy, but can bite if provoked)
HumanInteraction.Notes: Has a unique scent often compared to buttered popcorn

FunFacts: Binturongs are one of the few carnivores with a prehensile tail.
They use their tails to grip branches while climbing.

Habitat.Distribution: Tropical and subtropical forests, grasslands, and scrublands in Asia

PhysicalTraits.Size: Estimated: 2-3.5 meters tall at shoulder, 5.5-6.5 meters long
PhysicalTraits.Color: Gray to brownish-gray
SpecialTraits: Large ears (smaller than African elephants), long trunk
Tusks (in some males), large columnar legs

Behavior.Communication: Trumpeting, rumbling (infrasound), roars, rumbles, tactile communication, scent marking

Reproduction.GestationPeriod: Approximately 18-22 months (longest gestation of any mammal)

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: Medium to High (can be dangerous if provoked or protecting young)
HumanInteraction.Notes: Cultural icon, keystone species for forest ecosystems

FunFacts: Asian elephants have smaller ears compared to African elephants.
They use their trunks for breathing, smelling, touching, grasping, and drinking.

Habitat.Distribution: Wide range of habitats including forests, grasslands, mountains, and deserts across Africa and Asia

PhysicalTraits.Color: Pale yellowish to deep gold with black rosettes (spots)
SpecialTraits: Excellent climbers (can drag prey into trees)

Behavior.Communication: Roars, growls, purrs, raspy coughs, scent marking

Threats: Poaching for fur and body parts

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: Medium to High (can be dangerous if cornered or threatened)
HumanInteraction.Notes: Most widely distributed wild cat species

FunFacts: Leopards are opportunistic hunters and have a very diverse diet.
They are incredibly agile and can leap long distances.

Classification.Species: Various (e.g., Manis javanica for Sunda Pangolin)

Habitat.Distribution: Tropical forests, grasslands, and savannas across Africa and Asia

PhysicalTraits.Size: Estimated: 30-100 cm (body), 26-70 cm (tail) depending on species
PhysicalTraits.Color: Brownish-gray, covered in hard, overlapping scales
PhysicalTraits.Lifespan: Estimated: Up to 20 years (in the wild, estimated)
SpecialTraits: Covered in keratin scales for defense
Long, sticky tongue for catching insects (up to 40 cm)
Can roll into a tight ball when threatened

Behavior.Communication: Hissing, sniffing, tail movements (infrequent vocalizations)

Threats: Illegal trafficking for meat and scales (traditional medicine)

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: Low
HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Protected (most trafficked mammal in the world)
HumanInteraction.Notes: The only mammals covered in scales

FunFacts: Pangolins lack teeth and rely on their strong stomach to grind food.
They are sometimes called 'pine cones with legs'.

Habitat.Distribution: Tropical rainforests of Southeast Asia

PhysicalTraits.Color: Black fur with a distinctive yellow/orange crescent-shaped chest patch
PhysicalTraits.Lifespan: Estimated: 20-25 years (in captivity, less in wild)
SpecialTraits: Long, sharp claws for climbing and digging
Long tongue (up to 25 cm) for extracting honey and insects

Behavior.Communication: Grunts, roars, growls, huffs, scent marking

Threats: Poaching for bile (traditional medicine) and paws (delicacy)

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: Medium (can be aggressive if threatened or protecting cubs)
HumanInteraction.Notes: Known for their love of honey

FunFacts: Sun bears have very loose skin, which allows them to turn and bite an attacker even if grabbed.
They are excellent climbers and often build nests in trees.

Habitat.Distribution: Tropical rainforests of Central and South America

PhysicalTraits.Color: Golden or reddish-brown fur, sometimes gray
PhysicalTraits.Lifespan: Estimated: 20-25 years (in captivity, less in wild)
SpecialTraits: Long tongue for reaching nectar and fruit

Behavior.Communication: Hissing, barking, squeaking, scent marking

Reproduction.ReproductionCycle: Estimated: Can breed year-round, 1-2 litters per year

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: Low (generally shy, but can bite if threatened)
HumanInteraction.Notes: Often mistaken for a primate due to its arboreal lifestyle

FunFacts: Kinkajous can hang upside down by their prehensile tail.
They are important pollinators of certain fruit trees.

Classification.Species: Various (e.g., Alouatta palliata for Mantled Howler Monkey)

Habitat.Distribution: Tropical forests of Central and South America

PhysicalTraits.Color: Varies by species (black, brown, red, golden)
SpecialTraits: Powerful vocalizations (howls) that can travel miles

Behavior.Communication: Loud howls (territorial calls), grunts, barks, facial expressions

ConservationStatus.IUCNStatus: Various (e.g., Least Concern to Critically Endangered depending on species)
ConservationStatus.PopulationTrend: Estimated: Varies by species, some decreasing due to habitat loss

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: Low (generally shy, but may defend if threatened)
HumanInteraction.Notes: Known for their incredibly loud calls

FunFacts: Howler monkeys have a specially adapted hyoid bone in their throat that allows for their loud vocalizations.
They are one of the loudest land animals.

Habitat.Distribution: Tropical and subtropical forests of Southeast Asia and the Indian subcontinent

PhysicalTraits.Color: Black and white plumage with a large yellow and black casque on the bill
PhysicalTraits.Lifespan: Estimated: 35-50 years (in captivity, less in wild)
SpecialTraits: Large, prominent casque on top of bill (hollow and lightweight)

Behavior.Communication: Loud trumpeting calls, cackles, growls, bill clacking

Threats: Hunting for meat, casque, and feathers

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: Low
HumanInteraction.Notes: One of the largest hornbill species

FunFacts: Female hornbills seal themselves into tree cavities during nesting, relying on the male to feed them.
They are important seed dispersers in their forest ecosystems.

Habitat.Distribution: Tropical rainforests and swamps of Southeast Asia

PhysicalTraits.Color: Black front and hind legs, black head, and a distinctive white or gray saddle on its back
PhysicalTraits.Lifespan: Estimated: 25-30 years (in captivity, less in wild)
SpecialTraits: Short, flexible proboscis (trunk-like snout) for grasping food
Unique black and white coloration for camouflage

Behavior.Communication: High-pitched whistles, snorts, clicks

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: Low (generally shy, but can defend if threatened)
HumanInteraction.Notes: The only tapir species found in Asia

FunFacts: Malayan tapir calves are born with a spotted and striped coat, which they lose as they mature.
They use their proboscis to sniff out food and to breathe when submerged.

Classification.Species: Various (e.g., Galago senegalensis for Senegal Bushbaby)

Habitat.Distribution: Forests and woodlands across Sub-Saharan Africa

PhysicalTraits.Color: Grayish-brown to reddish-brown fur
PhysicalTraits.Lifespan: Estimated: 10-15 years (in captivity, less in wild)
SpecialTraits: Large, forward-facing eyes for night vision
Long, powerful hind legs for leaping
Highly mobile ears for precise hearing

Behavior.SocialType: Solitary (foraging), but can sleep in groups
Behavior.Communication: Variety of vocalizations (loud cries, chirps, clicks, croaks), scent marking

ConservationStatus.IUCNStatus: Various (e.g., Least Concern to Near Threatened depending on species)
ConservationStatus.PopulationTrend: Estimated: Varies by species, some stable, others decreasing due to habitat loss

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: Low
HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Protected in some areas, commonly traded illegally
HumanInteraction.Notes: Known for their 'baby-like' cries

FunFacts: Bush babies can leap up to 2.25 meters (7.4 feet) using their powerful legs.
They mark their territory by urinating on their hands and then spreading it on branches.
